Two new coordination polymers [Ni(C6H10O4)(C10H8N2)]n(1) and [Zn3(C6H10O4)3(C12N2H8)2]n(2) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Complex (1) exhibits an interesting three-dimensional interpenetrating network, whereas complex (2) has a two-dimensional network. The IR and TG properties of these two complexes are studied. Furthermore, complex (2) exhibits photoluminescence.

Introduction

The construction of novel metal–organic frameworks has attracted considerable interest in recent years, owing to not only their intriguing structural motifs, but also their potential applications in catalysis, medicine, host-guest chemistry, and the promising photo-, electro-, and magnetic materials [1–3]. In general, structural motifs of these metal–organic frameworks are closely related to the geometry of the metal centers and the number of coordination sites provided by the organic ligands [4–6]. So, the combination of a metal “node” and a ligand “spacer” is important for the construction of novel metal–organic frameworks [7–9]. It is well-known that carboxylate ligands play an important role in coordination chemistry. A lot of organic aromatic rigid polycarboxylate ligands such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate have been widely used in the formation of metal–organic frameworks, which results from their high symmetry and structural predictability [10, 11]. Despite the rich coordination chemistry exhibited by rigid symmetry ligands, studies on flexible saturated aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands are less well reported [12, 13], probably because the flexibility of the ligands makes it difficult to predict the reaction products in such cases [14, 15]. The ligands have at least two intriguing structural features. First, different from the rigid dicarboxylate ligands, the saturated aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands exhibit conformational and coordination versatility due to the existence of single-bonded carbon chains. Second, they contain two bridging moieties, which can lead to various connection modes with transitional metal centers and provide abundant structural motifs. Nowadays, the strategy of constructing coordination polymers from neutral and anionic mixed bridging ligands has attracted chemists’ interest in that it not only leads to extended structures and functional properties, but also offers more controllable assembly process than a single flexible ligand [16–20].

Based on the above considerations, we choose adipic acid, 4,4-bpy, 1,10′-phen and 3d metal ions as reactants to synthesize two new coordination polymers [Ni(C6H10O4)(C10H8N2)]n(1) and [Zn3(C6H10O4)3(C12N2H8)2]n(2) under hydrothermal conditions. Complex (2) exhibits intense luminescent properties at room temperature.

Experimental sectionMaterials and methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, N, and H) were performed on a Perkin–Elemer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. FT/IR spectra were recorded in the range 4,000–400 cm−1 on a Alpha Centaut FTIR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. Photoluminescence spectra were measured using a FL-2T2 instrument (SPEX, USA) with 450-W Xenon lamp monochromatized by double grating (1,200 gr/mu). All measurements were performed at room temperature.

Syntheses

Complex (1) was prepared from a mixture of Ni(OAc)2, adipate, 4,4′-bipy, and H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2:2:400, stirred for 0.4 h, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb, and kept at 140 °C under autogenous pressure for 5 days. Calcd. for C16H16N2O4Ni: C, 53.5%; H, 4.5%; N, 7.8%. Elem. anal. Found: C, 53.1%; H, 4.7%; N, 7.7%. IR spectrum (cm−1): 1597(s), 1565(s), 1462(s), 1422(s), 1336(m), 1308(w), 1299(w), 1217(w), 1100(w), 912(w), 819(s), 801(w), 670(w), 631(s), 595(w), 540(w), 458(w).

Complex (2) was prepared from a mixture of Zn(OAc)2, adipate, 1,10′-phen, and H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2.5:2.5:500, stirred for 0.5 h, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb, and kept at 150 °C under autogenous pressure for 5 days. Calcd. for C42H46N4O12Zn3: C, 51.0%; H, 4.1%; N, 5.7%. Elem. anal. Found: C, 51.1%; H, 4.2%; N, 5.7%. IR spectrum (cm−1): 1600(s), 1531(s), 1506(v), 1441(v), 1437(s), 1306(w), 1231(w), 1107(w), 933(w), 855(m), 761(w), 733(m), 701(m) 646(m), 531(w).

X-ray crystallography

Single crystals of the above two complexes were glued on a glass fiber. Data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer at 293 K using graphite monochromated Mo/Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and IP technique. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL 97 crystallographic software package [21, 22]. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier map. Further details of the X-ray structural analysis are given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables 2, 3. Crystal data and structure refinement, atomic coordinates, bond lengths and angles, and anisotropic displacement parameters are available in supplementary crystallographic data (Tables S1–S6). Crystallographic data for the structural analysis has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, CCDC reference numbers 635591 and 635592 for complex (1) and (2), respectively.

Results and discussionStructure description

The single-crystal analysis reveals that complex (1) is an interesting three-dimensional interpenetrating network. There is only one crystallographically independent Ni atom in the asymmetric unit as shown in Fig. 1a. The Ni (1) atom is coordinated by four oxygen atoms, two from a chelating carboxylate group, and another two from two different bridging carboxylate groups. The Ni–O bond distances are in the range of 2.015–2.218 Å, and the O–Ni–O bond angles range from 58.32° to 149.65°. These Ni atoms are linked by two bridging carboxylate groups forming a binuclear Ni unit. Two carboxylate groups of the adipate ligands exhibit two kinds of different coordination modes with Ni centers (C16 and C17 of one adipate ligand are distorted into two parts in the position). That is, one carboxylate group to bridge two Ni centers using bidentate mode, while the other exhibits chelating mode to link to two Ni centers. Thus, adipate ligands are connected with Ni centers by covalent bonds to form a two-dimensional grid-like (4,4) layer. Such layers are further pillared by linear 4,4′-bpy ligands into a three-dimensional network possessing large cavities of approximately 11.059 × 13.477 × 11.794 Å3 as shown in Fig. 1b. Given the spacious nature of a single network, it allows identical networks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode giving rise to a 2-fold interpenetrating net, as illustrated in Fig. 1c. This means that the cavity mentioned above is occupied.

Different from complex (1), complex (2) is a two-dimensional network. There are two crystallographically independent Zn atoms in the asymmetric unit as shown in Fig. 2a. Zn (1) atom adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry coordinated with four oxygen atoms from three different adipate ligands with the Zn–O bond distances of 2.034–2.287 Å and two nitrogen atoms from one 1,10-phen ligand with the bond distance of 2.128(3) and 2.175(3) Å. Zn (2), which lies on an inversion center, has a distorted octahedral coordination geometry and connects with six oxygen atoms from different adipate ligands. One Zn (2) is linked two Zn (1) atoms to form a trinuclear Zn unit. The adjacent trinuclear Zn units are linked to the adipate ligands forming a two-dimensional network as shown in Fig. 2b. The three-dimensional network of complex (2) was formed by the π–π stacking interactions between the 1,10-phen ligands (interplanar distance 3.69 Å) as shown in Fig. 2c.

IR spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of complex (1) shows characteristic bands of carboxyl group at 1,597, 1,565 cm−1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,482 cm−1, 1,422 cm−1 for symmetric stretching. The separations (Δ) between γasym (CO2) and γsym (CO2) indicate the presence of chelating (83 cm−1) and bridging (175 cm−1) coordination modes in complex (1). The IR spectrum of complex (2) shows characteristic bands of carboxyl group at 1,600 cm−1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,531 cm−1, 1,437 cm−1 for symmetric stretching. The separations (Δ) also indicate the coordination modes in complex (2) [23].

TG analyses

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on the single crystal samples of complex (1). In the TG curve of complex (1), there is only one weight loss of 89.34% in the range of 355–540 °C corresponding to the concomitant release of 4,4′-bpy and adipate ligands (Calcd. 89.69%). For complex (2), there also only one weight loss of 79.31% in the range of 369–517 °C corresponding to the concomitant release of organic ligands (Calcd. 79.48%).

Photoluminescence

The emission spectrum of complex (2) in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 3. It can be observed that complex (2) exhibits intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 450 nm upon excitation at 325 nm. This suggests that the complex may be an excellent candidate as a potential photoactive material.

Conclusion

In this work, we successfully reacted 3d metals with adipate, 4,4-bpy, 1,10′-phen and synthesized two interesting coordination polymers. The successful synthesis of complexes (1) and (2) not only proves that hydrothermal reaction is a useful method in preparing new organic–inorganic hybrid materials, but also show the capability of hydrothermal reactions in constructing new coordination polymers from rigid and flexible mixed ligands.

elements.content: Two new coordination polymers [Ni(C6H10O4)(C10H8N2)]n(1) and [Zn3(C6H10O4)3(C12N2H8)2]n(2) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Complex (1) exhibits an interesting three-dimensional interpenetrating network, whereas complex (2) has a two-dimensional network. The IR and TG properties of these two complexes are studied. Furthermore, complex (2) exhibits photoluminescence.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new coordination polymers [Ni(C6H10O4)(C10H8N2)]n(1) and [Zn3(C6H10O4)3(C12N2H8)2]n(2) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Complex (1) exhibits an interesting three-dimensional interpenetrating network, whereas complex (2) has a two-dimensional network. The IR and TG properties of these two complexes are studied. Furthermore, complex (2) exhibits photoluminescence.

elements.content: The construction of novel metal–organic frameworks has attracted considerable interest in recent years, owing to not only their intriguing structural motifs, but also their potential applications in catalysis, medicine, host-guest chemistry, and the promising photo-, electro-, and magnetic materials [1–3]. In general, structural motifs of these metal–organic frameworks are closely related to the geometry of the metal centers and the number of coordination sites provided by the organic ligands [4–6]. So, the combination of a metal “node” and a ligand “spacer” is important for the construction of novel metal–organic frameworks [7–9]. It is well-known that carboxylate ligands play an important role in coordination chemistry. A lot of organic aromatic rigid polycarboxylate ligands such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate have been widely used in the formation of metal–organic frameworks, which results from their high symmetry and structural predictability [10, 11]. Despite the rich coordination chemistry exhibited by rigid symmetry ligands, studies on flexible saturated aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands are less well reported [12, 13], probably because the flexibility of the ligands makes it difficult to predict the reaction products in such cases [14, 15]. The ligands have at least two intriguing structural features. First, different from the rigid dicarboxylate ligands, the saturated aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands exhibit conformational and coordination versatility due to the existence of single-bonded carbon chains. Second, they contain two bridging moieties, which can lead to various connection modes with transitional metal centers and provide abundant structural motifs. Nowadays, the strategy of constructing coordination polymers from neutral and anionic mixed bridging ligands has attracted chemists’ interest in that it not only leads to extended structures and functional properties, but also offers more controllable assembly process than a single flexible ligand [16–20].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of novel metal-organic frameworks has attracted considerable interest in recent years, owing to not only their intriguing structural motifs, but also their potential applications in catalysis, medicine, host-guest chemistry, and the promising photo-, electro-, and magnetic materials [1-3]. In general, structural motifs of these metal-organic frameworks are closely related to the geometry of the metal centers and the number of coordination sites provided by the organic ligands [4-6]. So, the combination of a metal "node" and a ligand "spacer" is important for the construction of novel metal-organic frameworks [7-9]. It is well-known that carboxylate ligands play an important role in coordination chemistry. A lot of organic aromatic rigid polycarboxylate ligands such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate have been widely used in the formation of metal-organic frameworks, which results from their high symmetry and structural predictability [10, 11]. Despite the rich coordination chemistry exhibited by rigid symmetry ligands, studies on flexible saturated aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands are less well reported [12, 13], probably because the flexibility of the ligands makes it difficult to predict the reaction products in such cases [14, 15]. The ligands have at least two intriguing structural features. First, different from the rigid dicarboxylate ligands, the saturated aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands exhibit conformational and coordination versatility due to the existence of single-bonded carbon chains. Second, they contain two bridging moieties, which can lead to various connection modes with transitional metal centers and provide abundant structural motifs. Nowadays, the strategy of constructing coordination polymers from neutral and anionic mixed bridging ligands has attracted chemists' interest in that it not only leads to extended structures and functional properties, but also offers more controllable assembly process than a single flexible ligand [16-20].

elements.content: Based on the above considerations, we choose adipic acid, 4,4-bpy, 1,10′-phen and 3d metal ions as reactants to synthesize two new coordination polymers [Ni(C6H10O4)(C10H8N2)]n(1) and [Zn3(C6H10O4)3(C12N2H8)2]n(2) under hydrothermal conditions. Complex (2) exhibits intense luminescent properties at room temperature.

Complex (2) exhibits intense luminescent properties at room temperature.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, N, and H) were performed on a Perkin–Elemer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. FT/IR spectra were recorded in the range 4,000–400 cm−1 on a Alpha Centaut FTIR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. Photoluminescence spectra were measured using a FL-2T2 instrument (SPEX, USA) with 450-W Xenon lamp monochromatized by double grating (1,200 gr/mu). All measurements were performed at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, N, and H) were performed on a Perkin-Elemer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. FT/IR spectra were recorded in the range 4,000-400 cm-1 on a Alpha Centaut FTIR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. Photoluminescence spectra were measured using a FL-2T2 instrument (SPEX, USA) with 450-W Xenon lamp monochromatized by double grating (1,200 gr/mu). All measurements were performed at room temperature.

elements.content: Complex (1) was prepared from a mixture of Ni(OAc)2, adipate, 4,4′-bipy, and H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2:2:400, stirred for 0.4 h, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb, and kept at 140 °C under autogenous pressure for 5 days. Calcd. for C16H16N2O4Ni: C, 53.5%; H, 4.5%; N, 7.8%. Elem. anal. Found: C, 53.1%; H, 4.7%; N, 7.7%. elements.content: Single crystals of the above two complexes were glued on a glass fiber. Data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer at 293 K using graphite monochromated Mo/Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and IP technique. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL 97 crystallographic software package [21, 22]. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier map. Further details of the X-ray structural analysis are given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables 2, 3. Crystal data and structure refinement, atomic coordinates, bond lengths and angles, and anisotropic displacement parameters are available in supplementary crystallographic data (Tables S1–S6). Crystallographic data for the structural analysis has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, CCDC reference numbers 635591 and 635592 for complex (1) and (2), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single crystals of the above two complexes were glued on a glass fiber. Data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer at 293 K using graphite monochromated Mo/Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and IP technique. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL 97 crystallographic software package [21, 22]. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier map. Further details of the X-ray structural analysis are given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables 2, 3. Crystal data and structure refinement, atomic coordinates, bond lengths and angles, and anisotropic displacement parameters are available in supplementary crystallographic data (Tables S1-S6). Crystallographic data for the structural analysis has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, CCDC reference numbers 635591 and 635592 for complex (1) and (2), respectively.

The single-crystal analysis reveals that complex (1) is an interesting three-dimensional interpenetrating network. There is only one crystallographically independent Ni atom in the asymmetric unit as shown in Fig. 1a. The Ni (1) atom is coordinated by four oxygen atoms, two from a chelating carboxylate group, and another two from two different bridging carboxylate groups. The Ni–O bond distances are in the range of 2.015–2.218 Å, and the O–Ni–O bond angles range from 58.32° to 149.65°. These Ni atoms are linked by two bridging carboxylate groups forming a binuclear Ni unit. Two carboxylate groups of the adipate ligands exhibit two kinds of different coordination modes with Ni centers (C16 and C17 of one adipate ligand are distorted into two parts in the position). That is, one carboxylate group to bridge two Ni centers using bidentate mode, while the other exhibits chelating mode to link to two Ni centers. Thus, adipate ligands are connected with Ni centers by covalent bonds to form a two-dimensional grid-like (4,4) layer. Such layers are further pillared by linear 4,4′-bpy ligands into a three-dimensional network possessing large cavities of approximately 11.059 × 13.477 × 11.794 Å3 as shown in Fig. 1b. Given the spacious nature of a single network, it allows identical networks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode giving rise to a 2-fold interpenetrating net, as illustrated in Fig. 1c. This means that the cavity mentioned above is occupied.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure description

The single-crystal analysis reveals that complex (1) is an interesting three-dimensional interpenetrating network. There is only one crystallographically independent Ni atom in the asymmetric unit as shown in Fig. 1a. The Ni (1) atom is coordinated by four oxygen atoms, two from a chelating carboxylate group, and another two from two different bridging carboxylate groups. The Ni-O bond distances are in the range of 2.015-2.218 Å, and the O-Ni-O bond angles range from 58.32° to 149.65°. These Ni atoms are linked by two bridging carboxylate groups forming a binuclear Ni unit. Two carboxylate groups of the adipate ligands exhibit two kinds of different coordination modes with Ni centers (C16 and C17 of one adipate ligand are distorted into two parts in the position). That is, one carboxylate group to bridge two Ni centers using bidentate mode, while the other exhibits chelating mode to link to two Ni centers. Thus, adipate ligands are connected with Ni centers by covalent bonds to form a two-dimensional grid-like (4,4) layer. Such layers are further pillared by linear 4,4'-bpy ligands into a three-dimensional network possessing large cavities of approximately 11.059 × 13.477 × 11.794 Å3 as shown in Fig. 1b. Given the spacious nature of a single network, it allows identical networks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode giving rise to a 2-fold interpenetrating net, as illustrated in Fig. 1c. This means that the cavity mentioned above is occupied.

elements.content: Different from complex (1), complex (2) is a two-dimensional network. There are two crystallographically independent Zn atoms in the asymmetric unit as shown in Fig. 2a. Zn (1) atom adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry coordinated with four oxygen atoms from three different adipate ligands with the Zn–O bond distances of 2.034–2.287 Å and two nitrogen atoms from one 1,10-phen ligand with the bond distance of 2.128(3) and 2.175(3) Å. Zn (2), which lies on an inversion center, has a distorted octahedral coordination geometry and connects with six oxygen atoms from different adipate ligands. One Zn (2) is linked two Zn (1) atoms to form a trinuclear Zn unit. The adjacent trinuclear Zn units are linked to the adipate ligands forming a two-dimensional network as shown in Fig. 2b. The three-dimensional network of complex (2) was formed by the π–π stacking interactions between the 1,10-phen ligands (interplanar distance 3.69 Å) as shown in Fig. 2c.

Zn (2), which lies on an inversion center, has a distorted octahedral coordination geometry and connects with six oxygen atoms from different adipate ligands. One Zn (2) is linked two Zn (1) atoms to form a trinuclear Zn unit. The adjacent trinuclear Zn units are linked to the adipate ligands forming a two-dimensional network as shown in Fig. 2b. The three-dimensional network of complex (2) was formed by the π-π stacking interactions between the 1,10-phen ligands (interplanar distance 3.69 Å) as shown in Fig. 2c.

elements.content: The IR spectrum of complex (1) shows characteristic bands of carboxyl group at 1,597, 1,565 cm−1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,482 cm−1, 1,422 cm−1 for symmetric stretching. The separations (Δ) between γasym (CO2) and γsym (CO2) indicate the presence of chelating (83 cm−1) and bridging (175 cm−1) coordination modes in complex (1). The IR spectrum of complex (2) shows characteristic bands of carboxyl group at 1,600 cm−1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,531 cm−1, 1,437 cm−1 for symmetric stretching. The separations (Δ) also indicate the coordination modes in complex (2) [23].
elements.clean_text:
IR spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of complex (1) shows characteristic bands of carboxyl group at 1,597, 1,565 cm-1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,482 cm-1, 1,422 cm-1 for symmetric stretching. The separations (Δ) between γasym (CO2) and γsym (CO2) indicate the presence of chelating (83 cm-1) and bridging (175 cm-1) coordination modes in complex (1). The IR spectrum of complex (2) shows characteristic bands of carboxyl group at 1,600 cm-1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,531 cm-1, 1,437 cm-1 for symmetric stretching. The separations (Δ) also indicate the coordination modes in complex (2) [23].

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on the single crystal samples of complex (1). In the TG curve of complex (1), there is only one weight loss of 89.34% in the range of 355–540 °C corresponding to the concomitant release of 4,4′-bpy and adipate ligands (Calcd. 89.69%). In the TG curve of complex (1), there is only one weight loss of 89.34% in the range of 355-540 °C corresponding to the concomitant release of 4,4'-bpy and adipate ligands (Calcd. 89.69%). For complex (2), there also only one weight loss of 79.31% in the range of 369-517 °C corresponding to the concomitant release of organic ligands (Calcd. 79.48%).

The emission spectrum of complex (2) in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 3. elements.content: In this work, we successfully reacted 3d metals with adipate, 4,4-bpy, 1,10′-phen and synthesized two interesting coordination polymers. The successful synthesis of complexes (1) and (2) not only proves that hydrothermal reaction is a useful method in preparing new organic–inorganic hybrid materials, but also show the capability of hydrothermal reactions in constructing new coordination polymers from rigid and flexible mixed ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, we successfully reacted 3d metals with adipate, 4,4-bpy, 1,10'-phen and synthesized two interesting coordination polymers. The successful synthesis of complexes (1) and (2) not only proves that hydrothermal reaction is a useful method in preparing new organic-inorganic hybrid materials, but also show the capability of hydrothermal reactions in constructing new coordination polymers from rigid and flexible mixed ligands.

cln_elements.content:
Complex (1) was prepared from a mixture of Ni(OAc)2, adipate, 4,4′-bipy, and H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2:2:400, stirred for 0.4 h, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb, and kept at 140 °C under autogenous pressure for 5 days. Calcd. for C16H16N2O4Ni: C, 53.5%; H, 4.5%; N, 7.8%. Elem. anal. Found: C, 53.1%; H, 4.7%; N, 7.7%. IR spectrum (cm−1): 1597(s), 1565(s), 1462(s), 1422(s), 1336(m), 1308(w), 1299(w), 1217(w), 1100(w), 912(w), 819(s), 801(w), 670(w), 631(s), 595(w), 540(w), 458(w).

Complex (2) was prepared from a mixture of Zn(OAc)2, adipate, 1,10′-phen, and H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2.5:2.5:500, stirred for 0.5 h, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb, and kept at 150 °C under autogenous pressure for 5 days. Calcd. for C42H46N4O12Zn3: C, 51.0%; H, 4.1%; N, 5.7%. Elem. anal. Found: C, 51.1%; H, 4.2%; N, 5.7%. IR spectrum (cm−1): 1600(s), 1531(s), 1506(v), 1441(v), 1437(s), 1306(w), 1231(w), 1107(w), 933(w), 855(m), 761(w), 733(m), 701(m) 646(m), 531(w).

Syntheses

Complex (1) was prepared from a mixture of Ni(OAc)2, adipate, 4,4'-bipy, and H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2:2:400, stirred for 0.4 h, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb, and kept at 140 °C under autogenous pressure for 5 days. Calcd. for C16H16N2O4Ni: C, 53.5%; H, 4.5%; N, 7.8%. Elem. anal. Found: C, 53.1%; H, 4.7%; N, 7.7%. IR spectrum (cm-1): 1597(s), 1565(s), 1462(s), 1422(s), 1336(m), 1308(w), 1299(w), 1217(w), 1100(w), 912(w), 819(s), 801(w), 670(w), 631(s), 595(w), 540(w), 458(w).

Complex (2) was prepared from a mixture of Zn(OAc)2, adipate, 1,10'-phen, and H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2.5:2.5:500, stirred for 0.5 h, sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb, and kept at 150 °C under autogenous pressure for 5 days. Calcd. for C42H46N4O12Zn3: C, 51.0%; H, 4.1%; N, 5.7%. Elem. anal. Found: C, 51.1%; H, 4.2%; N, 5.7%. IR spectrum (cm-1): 1600(s), 1531(s), 1506(v), 1441(v), 1437(s), 1306(w), 1231(w), 1107(w), 933(w), 855(m), 761(w), 733(m), 701(m) 646(m), 531(w).

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on the single crystal samples of complex (1). In the TG curve of complex (1), there is only one weight loss of 89.34% in the range of 355–540 °C corresponding to the concomitant release of 4,4′-bpy and adipate ligands (Calcd. 89.69%). For complex (2), there also only one weight loss of 79.31% in the range of 369–517 °C corresponding to the concomitant release of organic ligands (Calcd. 79.48%).

Photoluminescence

The emission spectrum of complex (2) in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 3. It can be observed that complex (2) exhibits intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 450 nm upon excitation at 325 nm. This suggests that the complex may be an excellent candidate as a potential photoactive material.

Photoluminescence

It can be observed that complex (2) exhibits intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 450 nm upon excitation at 325 nm. This suggests that the complex may be an excellent candidate as a potential photoactive material.
